"Liquidity" is trotted out by Wall Street-types whenever someone starts to question some of their activities, especially when certain speculative transactions threaten the stability of the entire financial system. A recent example was the so called "flash crash", when certain computer-generated ultra-high speed transactions, based on algorhythms, caused a cascade of sudden huge losses in equity valuations. Suddenly, a few people were asking why this kind of trading should even be allowed, since there is no economic substance to it. The answer, and delivered by the usual suspects, with a straight face no less, "liquidity".

It's an all-purpose "justification", which means whatever the pretend-expert wants it to mean. The real intent is to keep the public-or regulators- from looking behind the curtain.

Mr. Schoen, the Democratic strategist quoted in this piece, and others in the chattering class are pushing a narrative to try to convince the public that underdogs can't win. Nothing could be further from the truth.

A Quinnipiac poll shows Sanders at 15 percent nationwide, 16 percent in Iowa, and 18 percent in New Hampshire. Compare Sanders' numbers to Jimmy Carter who "wasn’t even on anyone’s radar at this point in the campaign."

http://m.dailykos.com/story/2015/05/22/1386790/-The-Corporate-Media-Woul...

“Over the last 40 years, out of seven races in which the Democratic nomination was up for grabs—races, that is, when a sitting Democrat president wasn’t seeking reelection—underdogs have won the nomination either three or four times (depending on your definition of an underdog) and have gone on to win the presidency more often than favored candidates.

It's not uncommon for a suspect, while being arrested, to say something like "I can't breathe" or "You're hurting me" to fake it, particularly when they resisting arrest like Garner was.
We call this Monday morning quarterbacking, dude, where you get to create both the facts, the outcome and the causes for yourself. Man, I am glad you are not a cop!

There is only one fact that matters in this case. The video recording was taken many feet away from the incident. Mr. Garner can be clearly heard to say "I can't breathe." The officers were right on top of him. If the camera mike could pick up the words, then the officers ears could pick them up too.

I don't care what the situation is, what the crime is, how many or how few officers, when someone in the process of being restrained says "I can't breathe", that means he is dying. Loss of air is a critical life threatening condition. Factor in the size of and poor health of the person and the situation becomes hypercritical. But even that doesn't matter. The man said he couldn't breathe. At that moment, they should have rolled off of him, if only for a few seconds, to assess the situation.

The conclusions drawn could be:
1) They heard the words and didn't care. This is depraved indifference or negligent homicide.

2) They heard the words and didn't grasp their meaning. In that case they are too stupid to wear the badge.

3) They were so pumped up on adrenaline that they could not control themselves and went into a gang attack mode. In that case they don't possess the composure and confidence to wear the badge.

It take a very special person to do police work. Exercising good judgement during intense physical encounters is very difficult to do. Much easier if the guy at the bottom of the pile is treated as human being and not a thing.

One cannot be arrested except under a warrant or probable cause. Even then, the arrestee is entitled to resist excessive force in the arrest - not the arrest itself - but excessive force used to effect the arrest.

Mr. Garner was choked to death during his arrest for illegal tobacco sales.

If ever there were a case in which excessive force was used incident to an arrest, this would be it.

Why do you think this? Is it the fact, or is it because you don't believe that in some tests placebos beat the supposedly active drug?

I listened to a long report on NPR about this drug. In tests, a placebo worked better than this pill. Barely anybody who took the drug felt any difference. I forgot the exact amount but it was less than 1 percent. The company that produces it first tried to get it approved as an anti-depressant but it failed those tests, too. Since they can't sell it by claiming it works, the company is trying to get people to back it by saying it evens the playing field for women. But, tests show it doesn't work. So do we really need to take a drug that is proven to work less well than a placebo?
